title: Abbey Pain Scale for Dementia Patients
description: Assesses pain in patients with advanced dementia who cannot verbalize pain through behavioral observation

parameters.name: body_language
parameters.description: Change in body language (restlessness, rigidity, defensive posture)

parameters.name: behavioral_change
parameters.description: Behavioral change (confusion, refusal to cooperate, aggression)

parameters.name: physiological_change
parameters.description: Physiological change (change in temperature, pulse, blood pressure, sweating, pallor)

parameters.name: physical_change
parameters.description: Physical change (tears, pressure areas, arthritis, contractures, previous injuries)

ranges.interpretation: No behavioral evidence of pain. Patient appears comfortable. Continue routine observation.
Evidence of mild pain. Consider non-pharmacological interventions (comfort, repositioning, relaxation). Monitor response and re-evaluate.
Clear evidence of moderate pain. Consider appropriate analgesia and non-pharmacological interventions. Re-evaluate after 30-60 minutes.
Evidence of severe pain. Immediate analgesia needed. Use WHO analgesic ladder. Re-evaluate frequently and adjust treatment as necessary.

references: Abbey J, Piller N, De Bellis A, et al. The Abbey pain scale: a 1-minute numerical indicator for people with end-stage dementia. Int J Palliat Nurs. 2004;10(1):6-13.
Australian Pain Society. Pain in Residential Aged Care Facilities: Management Strategies. Sydney: Australian Pain Society; 2005.

Liu JY, Briggs M, Closs SJ. The psychometric qualities of four observational pain tools (OPTs) for the assessment of pain in elderly people with osteoarthritic pain. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2010;40(4):582-98.
formula: Sum of the 6 domains: Vocalization + Facial Expression + Body Language + Behavioral Change + Physiological Change + Physical Change
notes: Developed specifically for patients with end-stage dementia
Assessment takes less than 1 minute to complete
Does not require specific training for application
Does not differentiate between pain and distress - careful observation after pain relief is necessary
Should be applied before and after pain interventions
Observational tool based on behaviors indicative of pain
Recommended by the Australian Pain Society and British Geriatrics Society
Each domain is scored from 0 (absent) to 3 (severe)
